comments.body: I love the look and function of them there really cool!

I have a few issues with how Chiselled Bookshelves act in 22w42a.

First, I don't like that you always take out the last book, it makes getting just one book out of the shelves extremely annoying, especially if it's the first enchanted book of the six, as that's six unstackable items, and you then have to put them back in.

Second, on a similar concept, I don't like how there's only one front texture regardless of which book is put in. It would make library builds quite annoying to find a specific book type in. Perhaps if there was some way to have it so depending on the book, it'll have a different design, allowing for all enchanted books, written books, writable books/book and quills, and plain books, to be recognizable at a glance, and combined with the first part, pulled out when needed.

As a combination thought of those two ideas, possibly hovering over a book in a bookshelf could show you the name, if renamed (or a named written book), or the enchantment for enchanted books? It could get slightly intrusive, but item frames have something similar already.

Thirdly, the sound books make is oddly clunky to me, sounds way more wooden than I'd expect, it could be a bit softer feeling to represent the sounds of paper hitting the shelf, rather than what feels like wood hitting wood.

The feature definitely has a lot of potential, but it feels a bit overly restricted as it is currently.

i want to give a suggestion about the newly added "chiseled bookshelf"

it has 2 problems

1- if you try to get the book you first placed you need to get all of the books instead of this i think it would be better if we could place books to wherever we want and get them individually

2- you can't quite distinguish the books on the shelf i think it would be nice if stuff like enchanted books, book and quil had different textures to distinguish them from one another

Here's a suggestion!
Chiseled bookshelves (and classic bookshelves) of every wood type in the game! This would fit with the update, as the different variants would help to increase the levels of storytelling, and it would be a nice quality of life feature. I hope any mojang employee that sees this would consider it, as I'd love to see it in the next update
Hoppers should interact with chiseled bookshelves
They should interact with hoppers. This could be useful in redstone contraptions and would allow you to have chests full of books that would automatically "re-stock" the bookshelves with books.
Old bookshelves can now be removed from the game, similar to how zombie pigmen were removed with the addition of zombified piglins.
The texture of the filled shelves is always the same, I can't remember what is where. And in order to take out the first book, I have to shake out the whole block, the shelves do not work like that.
Change the craft of the pulpit.

With the chiseled bookshelf we need a way to differentiate the books on the shelf. When we can color them we will have the ability to tell them apart so we do not spend hours taking books off shelves trying to figure out which is which. Leather is a material that is able to be dyed so this makes sense because Minecraft books are all made of leather.
Please add all wood variants too book shelves as well as chiseled book shelves.

It is a nice addition but it is a bit under exploited. I mean I thought we would be able to put our book on the spot we want. An interface would be really noice too, we have no way to recognize which book is in what spot.
Can Enchanted Books show the enchantment glint when placed in the Chiseled Bookshelf?
It would be nice if you would be able to choose which book you want and not only the last inserted
Minor thing: When copying a chiseled bookshelf with nbt-data and then placing it back down, it doesn't show the books, but drops them when destroyed.

Interaction with the chiseled bookshelf should be tweaked so that the player can grab the book which is targeted by the crosshair instead of taking the last one which was put in.

Edit: And please no UI as some are suggesting. Direct interaction with the chiseled bookshelf is very intuitive.

Edit 2: I'm not sure about this one but maybe the name of the book should be displayed (like a name) when you focus a book with the crosshair?

You should be able to grab any book from the shelf. It is very annoying to have to take every book off the shelf just to get the first one. Also when you hover over the book it should display the name of the book.

It would be great if the chiseled bookshelves didn't require silk touch. I understand why normal bookshelves need silk touch, because of the books, but the chiseled bookshelves are empty by default. I think it makes sense for empty chisel bookshelves to drop without silk touch. Chiseled shelves with books should drop the bookshelf and its contents separately.

- It is a shame how clunky the interactions are with the bookshelves, as in order to get out the first book of a full bookshelf you need to remove all the others. This is a really awful design choice imo. Either you should be able to remove the book that your crosshair is over, or give it an inventory that you can open. With the latter option, you can also hover over the book to see what it is without removing it which would be useful.

- I think it would be better if the bookshelf could hold 10 books that are each two pixels wide with a gap between them instead of only 6 books (or even 12 with no gaps) as this would make them more useful for storage as well as decoration.

- It would be cool if enchanted books have an enchantment glint when they are on the bookshelf, or another way to differentiate enchanted books from regular books.

- With the introduction of the chiseled bookshelf I think it is about time to add bookshelves for each wood variant

Chiseled bookshelves should contribute levels towards enchantment tables based on how many books they hold!

You could remove books from them to lower the level of enchantment you get, instead of placing torches between the enchantment table and bookshelves like you do now.

Please consider adding hopper interactions, it would be great if you could automatically add your collection of enchanted books to a bunch of chiseled bookshelves. You could also use it for aesthetic reasons like creating a magic library where the amount of books in a bookshelf is constantly changing.

As others have already said, perhaps enchanted books should have their own unique textures.

Not only that, but allow us to place and take away books from the "slot" we're looking at.

 

I also think that chiseled bookshelves should have unique mechanics when near enchanting tables.

For example, if an enchanting table is surrounded by a chiseled bookshelf filled with enchanted books, then the table is more likely to enchant tools/armor with whatever enchantments are stored in the shelves. Of course treasure enchants will not work. This may better incentivize the players to explore and essentially "level up" their enchanting table set with the desired enchantments
Storing only 6 books feels very wrong for a game where everything is base-8

I have multiple suggestions about the new chiseled bookshelves:
1. Changing the name to something like "bookrack" or so. The new bookshelves aren't chiseled like stone bricks, sandstone or netherbrick.
2. Let us place and take books from any slot in the rack. Perhaps even with different textures based on book type. Blank Books, Writable/Written Books, Knowledge Books  (if you give them in creative), Enchanted Books
3. Bookracks should count toward enchantment table levels, based on how many and what type of book is inside of them. E.g. Full of blank or written books = +1 level, half blank/written; half enchanted books = +2 levels, full of enchanted books = +3 levels.

Different textures for the type of book stored (book, book and quill, writen book, enchanted book)
And being able to take the book from the slot you're looking at. This would make the bookshelves much more useful, easy to use and also allow for some fantastic customization of libraries etc.
Chiseled bookshelves when full should power enchantment tables.
Give bookshelves a chest UI so you can tell what is inside of them.

you should be able to choose what position the book is in. for example 6 books fit on a bookshelf.  i put 3 at the top and 1 on the bottom left and 1 in the bottom right, the book on the bottom left should look like its fell over like the original bookshelves. 

another example should be, if I want to place 2 books on top and 2 books on the bottom. what I'm getting at is bookshelves should be more customizable with some sort of tribute to the original with the knocked-over book until a book is put in that place.

i also think with this could come books that are put on their side. like if I put one in the middle of the shelf (top or bottom) the book should lay down flat as if just placed there.

As said before, chiseled bookshelf should have or:

a chest GUI so you can pick the desired book

just any other way to get the specific book you want instead of having to get rid of all books to get the book you want.

I think the Comparator behavior on Chiseled Bookshelves is really confusing at the moment. A similar idea would be to indicate the last active slot (e.g. the last Book that was placed, not removed). The output is still different from Chests and is very similar to the current one, but it's also familiar because Lecterns behave almost the same way when interacting with Comparators.
A GUI seems problematic if these are only for books, otherwise any item can be stored in these.
What if each book type displayed their own texture for better recognition (like enchanted books are purple, book and quill are brown, and regular books are any other random colour)?

In the stronghold library, Woodland Mansion and all villages that have librarians, you should add at least one or two chiseled bookshelves containing enchanted books. It would give a far greater incentive to visit these places!
There should be a special UI for chiseled bookshelves.
The functionality is fine, but the texture feels too plastic-y, in my opinion.
What if it had a GUI where the 6 slots only accept the three book types and no other items? Like how the enchanting table only accepts lapis in the one slot.
I think the chiseled bookshelf needs a gui like a chest but smaller like a llama.
The texture is dark so enchanted books should like lit it up likes its giving some enchanted to the bookshelf itself.

These bookshelves are a step in the right direction for Minecraft, giving actual functional furniture for players, and I hope there's more interactable shelves, crates and whatnot in the future. Having to build furniture using buttons and item frames look ugly, and makes the game laggy in large amounts.
Please allow Chisled Bookshelves to be loaded and unloaded using hoppers and dispensers.
Can you add a new structure that contains chiseled bookself? I would love to see this

It is a great addition to minecraft and we need more things like this. The only down side is that it can only hold 6 books where as bookshelves look like there's about 20 or more books it should hold at least 6 more
I think it should be 8 books per bookshelf. Also, enchanted books should have a tint on the book texture.

Disagree on needing chest UI. Being able to put books in/out directly makes it unique and how a bookshelf actually works.

More books would be good plus the scaling of books in regular bookcase would match better. Also, obviously being able to access each book slot individually would be great, as well as texture for book in slot matching the book in the slot.

And hopper/dispenser functionality would be great.

These Bookshelf are Great! But, I think when we put a enchanted book in the Bookshelf. Each Enchanted Book should be a different color or design! Frost Walker would be a blue book and Fire Aspect would be a Red book with Flames!

I think it would be a great idea to replace most of the bookshelves in stronghold libraries with chiseled bookshelves, and remove the loot chests altogether. The chiseled bookshelves would hold books, and would occasionally hold an enchanted book or a book and quill. Instead of just walking in, breaking a couple cobwebs, and taking the enchanted books from the chests, players would need to thoroughly clear out the cobwebs to check all the bookshelves for the special loot that could be hiding amongst the ordinary books. It would make the libraries much less generic and offer a fun challenge when looting them.
Should add the ability to put other display items on there as well! Even if it's only a few (think potions and mob heads!) Also, a UI similar to enchanting tables to see what books/items are inside!
The fact that you can't pull out individual books from the slot you are looking at is very disappointing. The bookshelf is far less useful than just a chest of books.

Muito boas porém, acho que poderia ser usada dos dois lados, fico imaginando os corredores de uma biblioteca mas como está agora as estantes teriam que ter dois blocos de largura pois só podemos por livros de um lado, se desse pra usa dos dois lados as estantes teriam um bloco de largura com 6 livros de cada lado. Quanto aos livros acho que como já disseram alguns aqui eles tem que cada um tem que ter uma textura única para que possamos identifica-los na prateleira ou até uma forma de customiza-los e possamos tirar apenas o livro que o mouse está apontando não ter que esvaziar a prateleira para tiramos o ultimo livro.

I would like to see chiseled bookshelves count towards an enchanting table.

This seems like a great opportunity to have more diverse options for a full enchanting table setup, and could even add some handy book storage within reach of your enchanting table.

Another user had a similar comment suggesting the bookshelves should be full. Personally, I'd prefer if you can move books in and out of the shelves and still have them count.

(P.S. If the intent is to gate high level enchanting behind how many books the player has collected, then I'd recommend working a lectern or bookshelf into the crafting recipe for chiseled bookshelves.)
Ability to use for enchanting table but unlike normal bookshelves that have only 3 books you can reach level 30 with the chiseled ones with only 7 because they contain 6 books

Very good, however, I think it could be used on both sides, I'm imagining the corridors of a library but as it is now the shelves would have to be two blocks wide because we can only put books on one side, if you could use them on both sides bookshelves would be one block wide with 6 books on each side. As for the books, I think that, as some have said here, each one has to have a unique texture so that we can identify them on the shelf or even a way to customize them and we can only take out the book that the mouse is pointing to not having to empty the shelf to take out the last book.
Make that we can see the name of the book please

A little annoying that whence you have the items required to make a chiseled bookshelf it doesn't show up in the recipe book, at least not yet. Even when looking at it while at a crafting table it doesn't appear. Might need to look into fixing that oversight.
You should be able to choose which book you grab by the one you look at instead of automatically choosing the last one and vice versa for placing the books in the shelf.

I would like to be able to change the color of my books in the bookshelves with dye and/or gold/iron nuggets for buckles on the books and the color of the leather. I would also like to be able to pick a specific book from the bookshelf if I clicked on a specific book.
What if we could also store maps in chiseled bookshelf? Or in similar block
The book and quill doesn't save your written text, but I can't even sign a book and quill in Minecraft preview. So I guess it's not just the Chiseled bookshelves are the only issue.

The books look so thick, and its weird. I think it would be better if we could place 2 more on it, so the books are thinner. Also 6 is a small amount for bookshelves when the original holds like 15. I think it should have a chest gui too so we can tell what books we are grabbing. Plus depending on the type of book the texture should be different. Enchanted books would shimmer, normal books would be a blank color, a book in quill could have a band around it. White if it isn't completed, and gold if it is. Also say someone mentioning dying books, and that would be so cool! Also would love different wood versions for normal, and chiseled shelves

I think it should be possible to use chiseled bookshelf with an enchanting table. Maybe make it so they have to be full. I mean if comparators can detect why not enchant tables? Normal bookshelves have 3 books but these would need 6, so that will be a balancing factor. Someone might not use any chisled at all while some might use both. It should be possible to do both right? Just like how you can have random mineral beacon bases? It just needs to fit the configuration. So an enchant table can detect both chiseled and normal bookshelves but it'll consider unfilled bookshelves as empty block space?

When you right-click using an axe on a Chiseled Bookshelf it could do one or both of these:


1. Adds/Removes space for more books, so you’ll have multiple different states (Example: State 1; 6 books, state 2; 9 books & state 3; 3 books).
2. When used on a solid side it will create shelves on that side (Example: Right-clicking the back side will open space to put 6 books, so you’ll have the front and the back to put more books).

Suggestions:

  • The storage needs to be buffed, both due to the visual difference between the regular bookshelf and the fact that you can already store 27 books in block, using a barrel. Having for example 16, 8 per row would match redstone signal from a compator nicely.
  • If upped, the need for point-to-the-book-you-want-and-get-that-out increases a lot. Even with just 6 like in 22w42a, it's too annoying storing books this way, as if you need the first you put in, you need to get all 6 out.
  • Comparator needs to be calculated by fill-level for parity with other container blocks. The mechanics in 22w42a makes no sense to use, what so ever, and is really counterintuitive.
Add The ability do dispense books for red stone and other things
I SAY COLORED BOOKS !11!1!1!1!1!1!
Clicking on them should open an Inventory like a chest with 6 slots in a 3x2 grid. Then you can choose which book you want to get off the shelf

I would really like it if more items were allowed to be put into the bookshelves, with things like potions/water bottles, skulls, or bundles able to put on the shelf, allowing extra texture variety as well as a fun way to give gifts, make puzzles, and prank your friends
It would be cool if dispensers could insert a book into a chiseled bookshelf

I really hope that the chiseled bookshelves will have a ui that can be accessed by crouching then interacting, as currently the only way to get to a book that isn't the last one placed, is to remove until you get to the book you want.
If theres a possibility for texture varriance besides number of books in it, chizeled Bookshelves should be able to store potions and bottles.

I have a couple ideas for the chiseled bookshelf, first off all I think it is a good addition to the game already, but there are a couple that if changed would be better.
1. Make it interact with redstone.
If you could be able to put items in and out with hopper(minecarts), dispensers, then you can for example easily improve for the door showed in Minecraft Live by being able to put the book in a hopper on the other side of the door and that goes back to the chiseled bookshelf to refill it and close the door again. This allowes you to easily create a system to close the door at any time you want. For example if you want to let more people through you won't be annoyed by having a too short clock to let everyone through. Another example is to easily sort enchanted from a farm so people that aren't so good at redstone don't have to watch a complicated tutorial about that.
2. Being able to put/take books somewhere else than the first available/full spot. (Only when they are manually put in the bookshelf)
This could be done by if you look at the spot on the bookshelf while your putting the book in it goes there, when the spot is full you get the book that was there
This is good for decoration purposes and maybe people that maybe want to create pixel art with it.
3. When you rename a book and put it in the bookshelf a name tag will pop up if you look at it or are in a particular range from the bookshelf.
This could help with finding a book back when you have a lot of books stored.

You should be able to have 2 different states of the chiseled bookshelf.

State 1:
A comperator takes the amount of books in the chiseled bookshelf as redstone output.

State 2:
A comparator takes the last spot interracted with as redstone output. Like it is now

I think the default state should be 1 cause that feels more intuitive and is easier to understand.
You can change the state by shift right clicking or powering the block with redstone.

I'm in the camp these new shelves should augment enchanting, either with a new block that will copy spells from the shelves (costing more XP and Lapis) or in modifying the Randomness of the Enchanting Table, potentially adding Treasure books into the list and increasing odds of high level enchants. Which honestly is my biggest hope for this block is an update on enchanting. And would make useful instead of just a decorative storage compared to a barrel or chest.

A small GUI for the shelves would be easier to work with, or when looking at a book you get a tag on what it is. This should only work for player made shelves to keep the neat idea for dungeon libraries.
Going up to 8 books would be a perk, and more in line with other gameplay. And would require a little more work to power up an enchanting block.
They need a different name. Why “chiseled”?

I love the idea of a customizable and functional bookshelf in minecraft! I have a few tweak ideas I would love to suggest though, I have seen others mentioning it too:
-They should have a GUI like hoppers and barrels so I can see and specifically take out books that you want
-The books should appear depending on where they are in the gui
-Each book should have a specific color thats displayed no matter which slot it appears in, this way players can make full red or full green bookshelves, not just random ones.

Hope to see this idea get more refined, and looking forward to see what you are coming up next!

I don't feel like the name is on-point. Maybe "empty bookshelf?" It would be cool if you could pick it up after putting books in it, a bit like a shulker box specifically for books. It might make gathering loot and grinding for enchants a little bit easier. Also, I made a post about how putting specific enchanted books in the chiseled bookshelf around an enchanting table should increase your chances of getting that enchant from the enchanting table.
i think that it should be so if you shift click on a book you take out that specific book
Are normal bookshelfs now still usefull?

Suggestions:
I would love for the bookshelves to have more control where I place the book and where I take it out from.
A GUI would be a simple solution for that.

And if possible, that should also mean that 1 book would have the same color and shape in any of the slots.
Maybe could use dye or a some sort of book binding bench to change the appearance of specific books.
We should be able to store music discs within chiseled book shelves they should have a slightly different texture as well.

I have 3 suggestions:

1-Please make it so that the book shelf texture changes based on the wood you craft it with, it’ll make is so much fun to build with and will match a lot better in different atmospheres, if you do this please consider doing the same for the normal bookshelf

2-Please make it so I can take out any book instead of ALWAYS the first book

3- some sort of symbol on the spin to represent what type of book it is

It is great that we can detect the number of books stored using a comparator, but it would be better if it would actually detect the number of books rather than the last slot you interacted with. You can have an empty bookshelf with a redstone output of one, because it appears that the output doesn't come from the books. That means, you can also have a bookshelf with 5 books but an output of 6.

Dupe of https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/10000076541965-Chiseled-Bookshelf-One-side


Chiseled Bookshelf | One side

Well, I saw that, you can right click the chiseled bookshelf from any side, that isn't amazing, my ideia is for the block be right clicked only on the front side, and when taking/placing book, it's gonna be placed In the slot you're looking at.

Delightful! Finally, bookshelves can be used for something much more than just building blocks.

Maybe Librarians can pick up books from one Chiseled Bookshelf and move them to another?

What if we could find chiseled bookshelves in villages and strongholds, and they could have books inside them that tell legends, and/or clues to some ancient treasure that will be perfect for the lost Arceology update?

There should be a redstone book, crafted with a book and redstone dust.

So the chiseled bookshelf only emits a redstone signal with it, and the signal stength according to which slot its in.
Chiseled Bookshelves should be easier to break the less full they are. A full one should be comparable to a regular Bookshelf but an empty one should break much, much quicker.
I can't get them somehow
I can't get them somehow

I saw a twitter post about adding a nametag that describes the book you're looking at. I think that, combined with a spine texture that changes depending on the type of book would be neat. 

I also think that they should have some type of integration with enchanting. Maybe if you have a bunch of bookshelves with a specific enchantment on the books, it'll decrease the probability of getting that enchant in the table. (never making it impossible, but making it a bit rarer, since you already have enough of that book to fill up bookshelves)
I REALLY want this to be a thing. This could make a very good library.
This is also much easier to craft than bookshelves.

Dear Mojang team,

I think it would be good, that inside the chiseled bookshelf, the different types of book can have different textures, like a normal book brown, enchanted book glowy (and maybe have the initials of the enchant and the number). That would make us see what books are in the bookshelf from outside, rather than needing to take the book to see.

Also, if you redesign the stronghold, please put chiseled bookshelf in the library

Good development on the 1.20 excellent update

These new bookshelves are amazing! I have wanted this to be added for years. However, the method for adding and removing books does not work well. When you click on the shelf there should be a 6 slot inventory that opens. This will allow you to easily organize your books.

I think that chiselled bookshelves will be an amazing revolutionary new feature in Minecraft!

It would be great though if right clicking a book on the chiselled bookshelf would bring up the same interface as the lectern. This way you could know which book is which before making the decision to take it off the shelf. In real life bookshelves you can see the name of the book on the spine before taking it off.

This is a feature I've been wanting for a long time, specifically after these were updated to allow us to pick and choose specific books to take out. I understand this is a large scope of an ask, but it would be even cooler if the textures of the books inside the Chiseled Bookshelves matched the type of book that is in each slot. I'm wondering if this is more possible now, with the addition of paletted permutations!!
I would love to see a texture for each slot, be based on what book type was inserted. And allow Pack makers to define new ones. It'd make it slightly easier to see where certain books were stored.

It's been said a few times, but the Chiseled Bookshelf GUI really does need a UI. That's the only issue I have with this block.

As someone who's the key audience that Mojang is aiming for with the Chiseled Bookshelf, it'd definitely help improve the "lore" of builds, but I really wish we could see at least the titles of all the books in there. That's mainly why I'm suggesting this because I can't really think of any other way to see the titles of books stored on the bookshelf.

I can't make a mock-up image right now, but I'm imagining it would look kinda like the hopper's GUI except with one extra slot. Maybe the actual player inventory can be minimized, or the bookshelf can show on one side sort of like the horse/llama GUI.

This is probably my favorite block in Minecraft as of yet, but I think if a GUI is added, it'll be perfect.

Its finally time for bookshelf variants in each wood type.

Id settle for a dark oak version. Some contrast is sorely needed for both regular and chiseled bookshelves.
this has been needed for a while but hope there is some way to plan what your book will look like before you put it on the shelf even if its UI "published form" doesnt change

What about adding an inventory to this Block with 6 Slots so you can easy Take the First book without Put another 5 unstackable items in Ur inv also you can See what types of books are in the chiseled bookshelfs Just by hovering over the books and See the enchantments

They should bei found in Strongholds so we can delete the Cheats with enchanted books(i Hope U Guys will add them Back to the lootpool of stronghold libary chests) and replace them with the new Block filled with some enchanted books
Feels like they would be better if they had a chest/inventory interface so you didnt have to take everything out at once to get the first item placed in

I have one suggestion with the bookshelfs in the latest release.

It would be nice when a writen book is in the chisled bookshelf that it displays its name and auther in the actionbar when selected or hovered over with crosshair or touch control. It would allow players to know what book they are taking out instead of taking out each book one by one until you find the book your looking for.

Let the books be dyed and their dye color be displayed on the bookshelf.
Depending on what type of book is, it'll have different designs or features.
Normal books can be dyed or not and they'll show their color on the bookshelf.
Writing books can show a feather in the side on the bookshelf.
Enchanted books will have their glint when they're on the bookshelf.
Chiseled Bookshelves in Strongholds with books(entchanted, storys) in them🥺

The usage of the name Chiseled Bookshelves kind of disallows for any future creation of stone-made bookshelves - which I'm not here to comment on the importance of - but allowing for stone bookshelves' use of this name instead should be considered.
The thing I'm most interested in, in regards of bookshelves though, is the ability to make them with different wood textures. Oak bookshelves in spruce houses is a bit distracting
I love this idea, but it feels sad to get chiseled bookshelves BEFORE getting bookshelves for different types of woods.
I'm super excited for this. Not only could it help me make a library, but I could make card racks, newspaper racks at the subway station... the possibilities are endless!

It would be great to have more variants of the upcoming new Chiseled Bookself, depending on what type of planks is used to craft the shelf. 

For example, using Oak Planks, you'd get the standard Chiseled Bookshelf. Or if you used Cherry Planks, you'd get a pink variant of the bookshelf.

This change would let player have more options and have more ways to customize their builds, which fits this update (1.20) perfectly, especially now that Trims are coming to the game. "Customisation and personalisation." It would also fit in into the Storytelling aspect too, as building could be seen as a way of story telling.

We reaaally need to be able to distinguish books and take specific books. I was really excited for chiseled bookshelves but they're unusable in their current state, no point in storing books on something that makes it harder to organize. Wood variations with bookshelves would be cool but the formerly mentioned features are more important. I really want to use these in game
What about if you fill a chiseled bookshelf with a certain enchantment and put it near a enchantment table it makes it more likely that you will get that enchantment. Just a quick idea I had.

EACH TYPE OF BOOK NEEDS AN INDIVIDUAL TEXTURE TO BE ABLE TO TELL WHAT KIND OF BOOK IT IS! 

Maybe make them the same colour as they are as items? Brown for normal books, purple for enchanted books and red for book & quill.

P L E A S E

Primary Idea:

  • Expand the region that the enchanting table can accept power from bookshelves, to allow for hugely increased space for self-expression with the new chiseled bookshelves, among other decorative things.

Primary Goal:

  • allow the player to have more freedom of self-expression through creative arrangement of enchanting setups to integrate more aesthetically into builds without compromising function of full-power setups

Current System Issues:

  • bookshelves can only be placed along a set ring along the perimeter of a 5x5x2 space to power up an enchanting table-- a lack of space discourages mixing in the use of chiseled bookshelves that are meant to be an extension to player self-expression

Proposed New System:

  • use a 7x7x3 or 7x7x4 space centered on the enchanting table, where bookshelves can be anywhere in the 5x5 or 7x7 perimeter to power up the table

Further Notes:
Under this new system, chiseled bookshelves do not necessarily need to be made to be able power up the enchanting table, but it can be an option.  There may be some concerns expressed about how doing so might render the old bookshelves more obsolete, being worth up to 6 books contribution to the enchanting table power, compared to the standard bookshelf being 3 books.  However, the primary focus should be self-expression, allowing more ways to get creative with the new chiseled bookshelves, creating more beautiful, working enchanting setups that are simply not possible with the rather limiting current system.

Both of the new wood sets in this update are great, but I feel like there are many missed opportunities in the current state of bamboo blocks, especially given the plant's relevance to real life eco sustainability. Bamboo is a great alternative to wood, but it requires a lot more effort to refine.

1)Bamboo stripping is too reductive.

Bamboo IRL yellows after a combination of chemical treatment and heat. I think representing at least one of these would be better, though I'm partial to giving the smoker an exclusive recipe for drying bamboo blocks. Maybe a system like copper weathering as others have suggested, or using slime balls similarly to honeycomb.

2)Block of Bamboo is not a storage block.

Block of Bamboo should craft 9 Bamboo. This block should also be renamed to Bamboo "Bundle" (think Hay "Bale"). It can still be dried for the yellow texture. Bamboo Planks can now be crafted with 4 Bamboo Bundles.

3)No green Bamboo Planks/Slabs/Stairs

I think the current plank palette is sorely lacking green, so rename Bamboo Planks to Dried Bamboo Planks and add 3 blocks using the existing green texture. Also, I think Bamboo Mosaic should be the alternative to Planks in crafting (meaning no need for a green door, button, etc). Bamboo IRL needs to be cut into strips and pressed together to emulate hardwood lumber. Maybe rename Mosaic to Planks for clarity, and Planks to Mosaic, Slatted, or Split Bamboo.

4)No green Bamboo Fence

Personal gripe. Its recipe could use 4 Bamboo Bundles and 2 Bamboo.

A common player complaint is that Mojang kept adding useless decos, and this update's yet another aesthetic update. Now don't get me wrong, I'm a builder and I love hanging signs, pots, and cherry blossoms! But the devs focus too much on intrinsic player motivation, and there's almost no extrinsic motivation anymore (such as building for survival, raiding dungeons to get useful loot). Nether update's the only exception. Deep Dark's great, but the unique loot like the compass is not that useful & too gimmicky.

When I first played Minecraft, that rush of making your first base to protect yourself from scary monsters, farming to sate my hunger, and exploring to get better gear, that extrinsic motivation feels great and addicting! The intrinsic motivation of making a beautiful survival base is a cherry-on-top. But nowadays, most additions are just useless things like the Sniffer's flowers. They're great for deco but have no survival use. And survival is why I buy Minecraft. I don't want a 3D app like Blender, I want a game.

On top of that, the long-awaited mobile controls from 1.19 ended up bad, there's still no way to customize your button size/position & HUD, even though players kept asking for it. If I have customizable buttons on-screen that allows me to quickly switch to my torch (or food, or anything else), use it, and return to my tool, that'd feel great, instead of slowly tapping the tiny hotbar. Every good mobile game has button customization, except Minecraft.

As for update feedback, I love non-full blocks like signs. We finally have a new non-green leaf color with cherry blossom! I hope for brown autumn leaves in the future, with falling leaf particles. Please add ambient sounds like crickets, sea waves, caves echo etc. I was hoping for a green wood set with bamboo as we're lacking green fences/stairs.

Wandering traders should sell his unique armor trim as he's useless. Elder Guardian's armor trim drop rate is too low, and finding them can take 10k+ blocks. While the armor trims encourage exploration by giving unique structure loot, save file bloat discourages exploration especially on mobile/consoles. I find myself not wanting to explore & play the game, because as the file size goes into gigabytes, the game on bedrock starts to lag & crash. This lack of adventure makes me quit the game. What if there's roguelike temporary dimensions where you can go into a randomized dungeon world, fight the boss & get loot, then repeat? The End update is a perfect opportunity for this, fitting the dimension-hopping theme. What about magic wands & robes like Minecraft Dungeons? Everyone's using diamond gear with no variety.

Mojang is too afraid of making big meaningful changes & prefers "safe" but boring aesthetic updates. Many players wanted bosses & new dimensions with useful loot. Adventure needs dangerous areas with mobs like dragons & sea leviathans. Lately though, this 1.20 update has been boring. Still, thank you devs for the update!

I am a person who likes storytelling a lot. One way I do that is by coming up with my own history for my Minecraft worlds. The thing is, Trails and Tales is supposed to allow players to create their own stories, because the game is supposed to be about creating whatever you want. However, the archaeology feature impedes players from coming up with their own histories for their worlds, so I think that it should be kept with little suggesting one specific past.

Update 1.20 showed enormous potential. Old bookstore structures, plants that would spawn new types of trees, so many things. Update 1.20 could save Minecraft with amazing new features, but instead it makes me feel weird as it seems the developers didn't know how to focus on one thing and develop it
Will there be a tales and trails update part two?

These updates are making me rethink what I used to think about mojang. One thing that the community has already said and I notice that it is true, mojang is making the game more boring, with few varieties. Mobs are often peaceful and do not give players rewards when defeated. Goats, shiny squid, allays, sniffer, camels, axolotl, warden. What do all these mobs have in common? They are peaceful, have almost no interesting functions or have no drops. You can ride camels, but he is worse than the horse because he is slower, which is bad enough. Allay, serves a few times to pick up items nearby, and you barely use it. The game needs more challenges, like the combat snapshots that Jeb_ took in version 1.16. Where is all that interaction with other players that he released years ago? Is it in the basement of ideas thrown out of mojang? I'm still waiting for that combat update

Hmmm the sniffer seems like something that new players will never be able to find without a wiki.... Maybe eggs can rarely appear on ocean chests as well? I really really agree that there's too much useless decorations, if only we can brew new potions with sniffer flowers, then it'd at least have some survival use.

Minecraft caters too much to builders, but I buy the game due to its open world rpg nature.... I want tough battles, dungeons, new weapons and gear. I want to live in a cool base but I don't have time to spend weeks watching building tutorials and gather materials, and so I prefer to live in structures like mansions. Not everyone is a creative builder and they shouldn't be forced to build. It gets boring though, if only there's a builder villager NPC that helps me spawn cool bases immediately.

Oh, and please remove the double-click crafting on mobile that's added in 1.19 to 1.20. For example, if you want to craft two buttons, you might click twice, but with the new double click crafting, you are likely to craft an entire stack of buttons and wasting materials. The old method of hold-tap to craft stack is much better.

I don't mean to offend anyone by posting this, but I just have to let this out. I think I can speak for the whole Minecraft Community if I say, that we're are extremely disappointed in this update. The Minecraft updates you have been delivering us are getting worse and worse since 1.16. I get that you are currently working on other projects but that doesn't mean, that you can just neglect Minecraft Java. I have been enjoying Minecraft for more than nine years and it's sad to see Minecraft slowly dying. It just doesn't seem nostalgic and fun to play mincraft anymore...
I have never been so disappointed and I really do mean it.

I was very excited for this update and was very upset at how underwhelming it was. There were very few features and they didn’t seem interesting or well implemented.

Most of the armour trims look almost the exact same and then you have to use gems and ingots, some of which are very expensive, limiting the colour without adding any other benefit. 

For the pots there is one size and one colour. And while the engraving could be a cool feature they don’t stand out. My suggestion would be to have pots colourful with different sizes while being customizable like banners.

Archaeology is slow, underwhelming with the only things you can find being: a piece of pot, a spawn egg for an animal that doesn’t seem to do anything or an emerald. 

Everything in this feels unpolished and unfinished, without having any of that charm that made minecraft so popular.
As a Bedrock player, I'm sorry to say that I was more excited about the upcoming parities than the 1.20 features themselves.

I think that update 1.20.0 is 7/10 because it's an interim update (not a major one), it doesn't make any major changes to the game (mechanics, gameplay), I think it needs to add more troubles (monsters, traps) and more useless mobs, for atmosphere

You should remove the netherite upgrade because it spoils the spirit of minecraft which is to do as you please. And put a system of durability on the armor ornaments because duplication is not very credible for minecraft vanilla.Or the armors trims would work like banner designs: unbreakable, because they are only cosmetics.

Ehhh I think that spirit of minecraft on doing as you please should be restricted to creative mode. In survival mode, I want dangers and restrictions like the warden.... If I become an unkillable god that can do as I please, the game gets boring, it's no different than creative mode... There's no sense of danger or rpg progression anymore.

But instead of making netherite equipment harder to get, maybe they should add more progression instead, or even different armor builds that's a sidegrade? I don't mind the smithing template dupe, they should really break off from being vanilla to add even more exciting things.

As others have already stated, this update feels very incomplete. There is a lot of promising stuff here with the Cherry Grove enabling a logical reason for more east asian inspired additions, Archeology opening up the entirety of the apparently more fantastical world of Minecraft's distant past and the updated Smithing System showing conceptual potential for creating more specialized equipment for different playstyles (perhaps letting those templates replace the overpowered diamond gear trades from villagers, which would rectify the busted diamond economy).

The problem is, the majority of the update barely scratches the surface of what these ideas could be expanded into, which sadly seems to be the norm over the recent years, the only part with deeper sandbox purpose instead being changes to previously underutilized elements like the sculk sensor and jukebox.

What needs to happen is to pull the brakes on anything completely new and give all the existing and especially the functionally useless and severely outdated stuff a second pass to make the game feel more cohesive and actually have the versatile sandbox, that it is primarily known for.

Minecraft is a sandbox game first and foremost. Please remember that, Mojang.

Update kinda feels half-baked.  I know it's main feature point is quality of life and bug fixes to of course the added physical stuff couldn't be as polished so I hope in the future what's there can be worked on even further like so many things before it.

Like, give the Sniffer even more plants to find than just two, give archelogy a different reason to go out of your way to do it besides self-expression, ect.

I hope the next update is more focused on polishing and upgrading what's been in the game for years already instead of focusing on completely new things.  Nether Forretresses and Strongholds come to mind.
I still want glowsquid ink to be used for armor trims

1.20 seems too messy and is the smithing changes are lame. For future updates I suggest that instead of adding random things into a jumbled up pile and slapping a title on it you should hold a series of update votes. This might seem like a bad idea, but, if done right, could help to bring a meaningful update to Minecraft.

First we, the players, give suggestions for a theme that the update would be focused on. Next you, the developers, choose a few that you think fit Minecraft best, then we vote on them. Once the theme is chosen we  submit various concepts. Then you would chose the best ones that fit the theme and we then vote on them.

Most people are saying this already, but the update feels underdeveloped.  

Cherry Grove: maybe the prettiest biome in the game, but it needs more unique features like a village type, biome specific mobs, etc to provide more functionality and intrigue than just for ambience and building. Ambience is one of Minecraft's biggest flaws and it NEEDS better ambience, but the biome just feels empty and will quickly grow boring as a result.

Sniffer: I voted for sniffers, but its the worst part of the update--tedious to find only for it to give two flowers used exclusively to decorate.

Smithing Table/Trims: good, but trims should provide minor effects like speed, damage, durability boosts, etc for the armor they're applied to, giving players actual reasons to find them beyond "they look cool." Maybe armor upgrading could be integral to the game--armors have abilities that stack when upgraded adding variation to combat (adding copper/emerald armor would help).

Archeology: interesting idea, but the loot isn't good enough for me to go out of my way to slowly dig through gobs of sand/gravel. The pots are really cool, but they need more variation (add colors or different pot sizes). The loot for archeology also needs more unique variation, maybe new decoration items, new weapons (which could help revamp combat), etc.

The additional blocks (shelves, bamboo, signs, etc) are cool, but these updates are all the same: add new blocks but change nothing big about the gameplay. Please take risks Mojang

I love this update but I have two suggestions for armor! Number one, more colors! For example, using prismarine for a light teal color! Other things that could be added are, leather for brown (There's leather armor, why not armor trim?), Nether brick for a dark purply maroon, blaze rod or blaze powder for a bright fiery orange (Copper isn't very orange), and Glowstone for a light gold color! Number two, armor coatings/shines! So you know how enchanting armor makes it shiny? I'm thinking of something similar. just think of armor with an orange shine on it! Some items that could be used for this are, magma cream for a gradient of orange and green, dragon's breath for white and purple, echo shard for dark blue, ender eye/ender pearl for dark blue and teal, and glow ink sac to make the armor glow in the dark! I would love to see these ideas in game. Once again, this is a great update but there could be more!

Minecraft is missing environment resources. The world is completely silent, it has no ambiance. If you walk around the world the same way you started playing, you'll end up never having heard crickets at night, fireflies at night, and frogs in swamps. Minecraft is an empty game
Armor is a very empty resource. If you don't have friends to play with you, there's no point in getting these armors. Armors don't even give advantages to the player. The full gold one could make the piglins accept the player, the copper one could maybe increase the player's speed a bit, stuff like that

I know this has been said by others, but I can't wait for an update that brings more extrinsic goals to the game or improves on what we have.

Minecraft is a sandbox game, which means we get to do what we want.  Well what if I want to complete a inset goal?  People love the nether update for that reason. It added new things to do and conquer.

Minecraft is a Survival game on top of a sandbox game. New toys to play with a are cool, but as a survival player, I want new challenges that help get me somewhere, yknow? This reason is why people want "usefulness" out of new mobs or items.

We wanna complete challenges and feel rewarded for what we do.  

Now I'm not saying to bottleneck players into doing something, because it goes against the spirit of minecraft or whatevr, but just. Give players a little nudge in the right direction.
I think it would be really nice if you can craft a horse saddle because those are hard to find if your in survival

Having a buildable in-game feature that shows your character’s updated location (similar to a “Locator Map” that moves with your character) and highlights any areas of interest to explore on the Minecraft map would be great. Because it’s almost impossible to locate the “Trail Ruins” locations without leaving on “coordinates” and referencing “Chunk Base” constantly.

I hope the next update is more focused on polishing and upgrading what's been in the game for years already instead of focusing on completely new things.  Nether Forretresses and Strongholds come to mind.

Make the old out-dated and, to be honest, quite ugly features (because they no longer fit Minecraft), more up-to-date, beautiful, and true to what Minecraft has become before adding more to the game!
Microsoft o Mojang propongo que en las librerías de las Strongholds pongan algunas estanterías con el nuevo bloque de estante, con algunos libros

A dev's reply to these feedback has been extremely disappointing, Mojang wants to keep adding useless content & I've lost hope that Minecraft will be better. I like Minecraft because of the freedom to explore an infinite 3D world where you can place blocks anywhere, and also the extrinsic motivations like survival, adventure for useful loot, battles/bosses. No other game in the world has this, they lack the freedom & most Minecraft knockoffs are mediocre. Bedrock doesn't have mods, so I need to rely on vanilla being good.

I love intrinsics, but the extrinsics are what made Minecraft this popular, creating youtube let's play reactions like getting scared by Wardens & feeling accomplished after defeating a boss. They're not mutually exclusive! We can have dungeons with tough mobs & useful rewards, where players have to make a choice to enter, not like phantoms harassing you everywhere as you build. We can give Sniffer flowers a survival use, not just decor. It's bad argument saying extrinsics are somehow ruining the sandbox, and justify adding useless items like goat horns & glow ink sacs, again & again.

All I do lately is build, build. That extrinsic reason that made me enjoy Minecraft is gone. So I've quit the game. I've decided that Minecraft needs competition. Hytale understands how to balance intrinsics & extrinsics, it's only a matter of time until players compare both games' updates, where one adds 2 useless mobs after a year, and the other adds meaningful additions.

I am disappointed. I have been watching some YouTubers play the new update and enjoying going to digsites and digging for a while.
Every digsites I have found so far has just been on the surface and nothing more. I really wanted to discover what they offered and find new sherds from the dig sites. But like I said everyone I want to was just one the surface nothing deep and big. Though the temple and well did have stuff more then I thought. It was nice to explore them. I'm in bedrock. I am overall very happy with the update!

A couple of features that excited me the most are the Sniffer and Archy, and I have several comments/ideas for both to make them more interesting to the average player/better for customization and storytelling.

Archy : :

Make suspicious sand & gravel craftable by placing one item in the center surrounded by either sand or gravel in order for players to create a minigame like experience amongst themselves. 

Make it possible for pots to hold an item inside (by crafting the item into it)

Have more exclusive items for Archy. Something like the Ruby may be a nice callback (fits with the ancient theme!), while providing nothing more than a trophy item (it would just be a collectable), which this game lacks. Perhaps another Totem would fit nicely here as well.

Sniffer : :

At least one more plant. A sapling could be a rather interesting addition

More hearts on the sniffer. It's massive, yet the slightest thing kills it.

Over all I really enjoyed the Sniffer and I believe dino mobs are untapped potential. Imagine you could obtain them in all different ways, perhaps a fish dino is frozen in the ice spikes and you have to take it back in the block and thaw it out, or maybe a small raptor-like mob that you find stuck in underground amber.

Unfortunately this update wasn't as exciting as I thought it was going to be a lot of things feels unfinished, there are some features that are also fantastic but the ones that aren't all there really bring the update down. To begin, armour trims are incredible and definitely something great for customisation, hanging signs the new wood types that's all great but the sniffer feels incomplete, so does the cherry blossom biome and to an extent pots too.

First the sniffer, 2 plants doesn't feel like enough. The amount of time investment to get the mob can be upwards of multiple hours and you receive 2 plants, there is a lot of potential for unique plants that the sniffer can dig up both edible and decorative and it is a missed opportunity (and feels unrewarding) to only get 2.

Second the cherry blossom biome, it is so close to perfection however the fact that there is no unique village for the biome feels like it is just out of place and undermines how the village and pillage update set up the feeling of the world.

Finally pots, this is a pretty simple one, firstly the lack of being able to colour the images, if we could ad die with a sherd to colour the picture (not the whole pot the picture) it would bring a lot more life to them, if the pot could also receive an inventory, they feel very stale (even though meant for decoration) having them as a storage option would give the player so many more options for thematic building (to fit with the storytelling theme of the update)

Overall, I don’t love nor hate the new update. It does give more to builders but that’s ok! Only real complaint is the sniffer egg and how out of place it looks compared to its spawn egg or the other obtainable eggs like the dragon egg or turtle egg.

Add armor slots in smithing table GUI to take or switch up armor directly in this GUI and not open inventory, switch down the armor, open smithing table GUI and apply a smithing template and re-open inventory to switch up the armor.

there's a dev twitter post recommending other games if you want extrinsic gameplay and it's not the goal of minecraft. well... but those rpg games like skyrim and terraria are very rigid and you're stuck in a map, not like minecraft where you can make anything. can't we have the best of both worlds? the dev mentioned adding extrinsic goals will ruin the sandbox freedom, but I don't see how that will happen, as players always have a choice to fight a boss or not. the boss might have a reward, but the game isn't forcing you to fight the boss, that goal is made by the player. but you can always do an intrinsic goal and make a castle instead. it's optional content, and I don't see why conservative players see it as ruining the sandbox.

despite some rude comments here and there, many of us criticize because we care about minecraft. please don't dismiss all feedback as toxic players simply being dissatisfied with every update. it's a bit sad to see feedback being ignored, and the devs trying to move away from survival mode....

i am sad that all the highly voted feedback in this site are going to be ignored, like bosses, dimensions, pet dragons, dog armor, quest boards, because it's *too extrinsic*. maybe i can instead compile all of the extrinsic feedback here before it gets removed, in hopes that a new rival minecraft-like developer actually makes the content im looking for. a minecraft game that doesn't force players to be intrinsic and find meaning in sniffer flowers.
really good update but will education ever get updated for those who play it?

Whenever Mojang adds something new or does an overhaul, it really does feel like they're afraid to go "all in."  New features and mechanics feel like they're only ankle deep. Like in just this update alone my two biggest sadnesses are:

Archeology: It's just decorations with the occasional gem, when either they could have had more decos or had some cool survival based loot or had more various structures spawn to dig in instead of just trail ruins.

Sniff: You have to search underwater for ages over something that... Digs up just two plants. I don't even mind that they're just decorative but why only two.  Why not five at the least?

And then in previous updates and overhauls, the cave updates only added three biomes to the caves, bit of a lack of variety I'd say also goes for the Nether update.  When you compare the overworld to the caves and nether it makes you want to ask for more variety when exploring.  Even with the ocean update, the oceans still feel empty because of a lack of life or perhaps unique areas to dive in for.

And even if the "loud minority" is very vocal about this sort of stuff, they do have a point. Physical features are feeling more half baked by the update.  Technical stuff is cool, but it's been years since I feel like I've been amazed playing the game.

I really think Mojang needs to take a step back and look at what's in the game *now.*  Entirely new things can wait.  What we need, IMO, is an update that takes what we have already, and polishes it.

Pillager Outposts have become rare to find now. I am on a mission to find the last armor trim which is the Sentry armor trim. It has literally taken me 4 days and I would have found one by now. Up the 25% chance to 50% chance. Also, more about the pillager outposts, they generate on the bank of rivers not on actual land.

I wish they could update the end by putting more things like structures, more blocks, mobs ect. In addition to the structures and that in the end they could put apart from the dragon and the endermans could also put other types of enderman such as sent, observed, artificer and trapper that are other different types of enderman with different abilities here I leave you a link of a YT video of the endermans as they could be. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G9Z7ZKc1mkc
minute 4:10 in the video.

Smithing table “improvements?” I don’t agree with that. I love this update (even though it is pretty underwhelming), but the smithing table changes are awful. I will never, ever, get netherite because I can’t even get diamond. The trims are a waste of time and diamonds. They are useless in single player! This change was a huge mistake. It would have been fine if you executed it properly, but you didn’t. Trims should have uses, netherite should grant fire immunity, and the templates shouldn’t be single use. That or make the templates like banner patterns, because they are the same idea but one is for banners and one is for armor.

I think that a small thing that would make a lot of sense and make players happy would be for the torch flower to glow. It doesn't need to be an over-powered thing or a complicated system. What makes the sniffer interesting at this point? It digs up two types of seeds, has an eight-minute cool-down to try to do so, and neither of these plants have any impact on gameplay. Other than that, the sniffer is unable to be tamed or ridden, will not attack hostile mobs for you, does not provide a food-source or useful material, and is a mob that is nigh impossible to obtain accidently. 

After searching out warm ocean ruins, facing the risk of drowning or dying from mobs, brushing suspicious sand and still only having less than a 7% chance to find an egg, you are rewarded with one of two, purely decorative, plants, once every ten minutes or so, if you're lucky and watching. Just make the torch-flowers glow.

Minecraft developers are not lazy, and neither is Mojang, I want to acknowledge that, But Minecraft is losing all of its charm and motivation to play very quickly. coming as someone who's been playing for a while, each update feels thinner and emptier, with less time being spent on worlds and servers with friends, i can barley pick up the game for 20 minutes without feeling I've exhausted everything I can do. Minecraft is adding more to the game, but they are all things don't make the game more fun or even give you more to do. they add more content but its all things I, along with a lot of other people, can really only enjoy for about 30 or so minutes before all of its charm is gone. 

to put it bluntly Mojang, and I am being 100 percent serious-

consider adding some of April fools update features as in game features, they're weird, but they're fun, interesting, and uniquely Minecraft. they're things that people genuinely enjoy playing with, they truly do make the game feel more creative and they give Minecraft a more Minecrafty feel than any update or mod that's been dished out in the past 4 years.

 

please give it some thought.

Generally I like this update only because of the cherry tree. All other innovations are somehow useless.
1.Camel does not have any benefits, drops or other unique uses. Being able to ride it with a friend is a good idea, but useless. Almost no one uses horses because people love elytras, so even more so no one will use a ground vehicle that can lie on the ground in the middle of combat + cannot wear armor or be at least something useful .
2.The sniffer is even more useless than the camel. No drop, hard to get, no character. For example in order for the turtles to hatch player must breed 2 turtles one of which will have a bally and a digging animation, after which the eggs will become vulnerable to monster attacks and, most importantly, eggs can only hatch on the sand, which makes it possible to use this in lots of decorations ideas. What about a sniffer? We get an egg, put it on a block of moss and after 10 minutes a mob appears. I personally don't have any attachment to such a creature for a variety of reasons, one of which is that the player doesn't feel involved. When I raised little turtles, I protected them and managed to fall in love with them, but the sniffer does not cause me emotions. Why can an egg hatch on any blocks? There are no interesting hatching mechanics, because the sniffer will hatch no matter what, which also deprives players of using the egg as a decoration. Well, the ability of the mob itself is bad. Two  flowers that do nothing but just stand is boring.

Let's break this down by feature: 

Cherry stuff - amazing overall, design and art are perfect, unique tree shapes are appreciated. Find the biome beautiful but slightly underwhelming - needs something unique (shrine? mob variant?) to feel complete outside of the petals. Blocks A+, Biome B+

Bamboo - love unique new wood designs - A+

Armor Trims - Awesome, but lacking a couple of options (prismarine crystals, crying obsidian maybe) and I think more trims should be added with new updates. A village trim, wandering trader trims. 
Also think the diamond cost is a lot for cosmetics (but agree with it for Netherite upgrades). A

Calibrated Sculk Sensor - makes a very useful but overly complicated side of redstone much more understandable and applicable. A+

Camels - hidden gem of the update for sure! We all know theres a power gap with Elytra, but I had a blast riding a couple of camels home to my barn. A

Archaeology - Fun, but incomplete. Great concept for a system but needs more reward than just pots and sniffer eggs (scrolls with ancient maps? ancient weapons? unique enchantment books?), C+

Trail Ruins - a bit too big, got almost everything unique clearing out just one. This should follow Archaeology recommendations, C

Sniffer - Great design and concept, underwhelming that the plants have little utility and there's only two. Hopefully gets iterated on. B-

Chiseled bookshelves - great, simple addition, appreciate the redstone too. A

Overall, 7.5/10 - lots of great stuff, some incomplete.

Its ok to take some more risks and add some adventurous content, dont be afraid to add to much content because part of the fun of the early days of playing minecraft is knowing that there is lots of undiscovered content.

This update is cool, but it feels like a spice rather than a meal. Though armour trims are a really good spice. Same with riptide, flint and steel, slime blocks, saddles, etc. It would be nice to have more blocks/items like those that have function.

I feel like the archaeology could've been better. When making the Caves and Cliffs update, Kingbdogz said "The image of stalactites & stalagmites comes into my head".

Well, if you say archaeology, the image of Fossils comes into my head. Although as I'm writing this, now I've discovered that fossils are specialized under paleontology, not archaeology. However, both of them excavate and study physical remains. 

SN: I know fossils are already a thing in Minecraft, but this way it will give fossils a new purpose & possibly new mechanics to the game.

According to Earthhome:

"Paleontology is the scientific study of fossils to learn about the history of non-human life on Earth.

"Archaeology is the scientific study of human-made artifacts and structures to learn about ancient people and cultures."

Many pointed out that the 1.20. update feels like it lacks something, in each sector. Well, I can tell you in the archaeology sector, paleontology is the way to complete it. To excavate & discover the remnants of non-human life fossils. The fantasy potential is also available, as you don't have to do dinosaur fossils, but can be a fossil of a Minecraft mob instead. New or existing.

To make it more exciting, you can use an item or do something creative (a new mechanic) to those fossils for a chance to revive them. With this, it can also be used to revamp how you revive the Sniffer, instead of just finding a Sniffer Egg.

Honestly, pretty disappointed considering that this update only added 3 notable features which, when compared to things like the nether update, are pretty boring.  All we got was one new biome that is only aesthetic, an underwhelming (and late) archaeology system, and armor trims that are pretty useless in general.  This really should have been more of a patch or been a part of a bigger update.  I would have rather waited longer if it meant there would be quality features.  Adding cherry blossom biome-specific mobs or structures would give more of an incentive to visit the biome.  Improving the archeology system by making the loot table better would give a better reason to spend most of your time looking for special blocks other than aesthetic reasons.  I would also like to see armor trims become actually useful like adding little bonus effects when applied.  Maybe the rib armor trim, (the one from fortresses), could grant a slight fire resistance.  In my opinion this update could be saved with a part two. however, for now, I wouldn't call this the trails and tales update, but rather the aesthetic update.

With the addition of the Piglin head and the added functionalities, I thought I might explore further possibilities and see what you guys think.

Additional Mob Heads: While I do not believe that EVERY mob needs its head to drop when exploded by a charged creeper, I believe there should be a couple more.

  • Iconic Mobs: Other iconic monsters such as the Spider and Enderman deserve a head drop as well.
  • Wither: It would be interesting if you could obtain a Wither head, though I think it would be through a different method like the Ender Dragon's head since it's a boss.
  • Warden: While this would go against what the Warden stands for by giving the player a motive to engage him, I still find this idea interesting. It would be another huge head similar to the Ender Dragon and when powered by Redstone, its antenna would wave like the Piglin's ears.

Additional Functionality: In spectator mode, you can look at the world through the eyes of an Enderman, Spider, and Creeper, and your screen is given a special filter. It would be neat if the same thing happened if you were to wear their respective heads. Of course, any new heads that are added will play their respective sounds when placed on a note block.

New Advancement: Even though the heads themselves are achievements, it might make for a cool advancement to collect them all.

I have this idea for sign icons. I was thinking about a new item maybe a stamp or a chisel. Something that can let you carve or print icons onto a blank sign. When you right click this item onto an unwaxed blank sign, you can choose from a selection of iconography to print a large icon boldly onto the center. It takes up about two to three lines. The UI is similar to the loom. One of the many reasons this can be useful is of course decorating. Imaging this. When you're walking down the streets of a minecraft build, you can see different shops. A hanging signs informs you of what shop it is. An anvil symbol may indicate a smithery. A grass block may indicate building supply. A sword may indicate weaponry.

Creeper, skull and crossbones, no entry, X, ✓, directional arrows, sword, pickaxe, anvil, grass block, ingot, mojang symbol, apple, mob egg, emerald, heart, iron golem, fire, redstone torch, wheat, pig, horse armor, globe, flower, warden, sound waves, bottle, dragon egg, eye of ender, guardian, bell, boat, zzZ (3 Zs diagonally), chestplate, cookie, firework rocket, elytra, music note, chest, rails, map, TNT, saddle, fishing rod, crafting grid, and flint and steel.
